title: Grandmaster Ratte' Profile
historical_context: This article provides insight into the hacker culture of the late 1990s, particularly focusing on the personal experiences and philosophies of a prominent figure in the Cult of the Dead Cow (cDc).
target_audience: Hackers, phreakers, security professionals, and those interested in hacker culture history.
short_summary: This profile of Grandmaster Ratte' offers a glimpse into his life, interests, and the evolution of the Cult of the Dead Cow. It reflects on the early days of hacking, the importance of creativity over mere technical prowess, and the future direction of cDc as a paramedia entity.
summary:
In this engaging profile, Grandmaster Ratte' shares his journey through the hacker scene, detailing his early experiences with technology and the formation of the Cult of the Dead Cow. He reminisces about the excitement of connecting with other young hackers via BBSes and the creative endeavors that emerged from those interactions. Ratte' emphasizes that cDc was never solely about hacking; rather, it was about using technology as a medium for creative expression and communication. He expresses a desire to evolve cDc into a paramedia organization, focusing on music and multimedia content distribution, which reflects the changing landscape of technology and creativity in the late 1990s.

Ratte' also offers pearls of wisdom for aspiring hackers, suggesting that a broader education in history and business may be more beneficial than purely technical skills. He warns against the pitfalls of becoming overly absorbed in technology at the expense of real-world experiences. The profile serves as both a personal narrative and a manifesto for a more holistic approach to hacking and creativity, encouraging readers to engage with the world beyond their screens.
